sen.j: 元々神道は海・山・川などを神体とする自然崇拝から始まったものであり、初期の神社では、そこに祀られる神には特に名前はないか、不詳であった。
sen.e: Shinto has its origin in nature worship, enshrining seas, mountains or rivers as shintai (object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity) and in early Shinto shrines, such enshrined deities have no particular names, or their names were unknown.

With its origins in the worship of nature, Shinto holds the seas, mountains, and rivers sacred as shintai (an object of worship at a Shinto shrine that is believed to represent the spirit of a deity) and in early Shinto shrines, either no particular names were given to such enshrined deities or their names are unknown.
sen.cmt: Given that Shintai is defined in the translation as meaning an object of worship *housed* in a shrine, saying that shrines enshrine seas etc. makes it sound like seas are physically housed at the shrine. As a result, I have had to "massage" the definition of "shintai" here. Please check.
sen.e: With its origins in the worship of nature, Shinto holds the seas, mountains, and rivers sacred as shintai (an object of worship at a Shinto shrine that is believed to represent the spirit of a deity) and in early Shinto shrines, either no particular names were given to such enshrined deities or their names are unknown.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 記紀や万葉集などでも、祭神の名が記されているのは伊勢神宮、住吉神社などごくわずかであり、ほとんどの神社の祭神は、鎮座地名や神社名に「神」をつけただけの名前で呼ばれていた。
sen.e: Only a few shrines, such as Ise-jingu Shrine or Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine, had Saijin whose names were clearly written down in Kiki ("The Kojiki", The Records of Ancient Matters and "Nihonshoki", Chronicles of Japan) or Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousands of Leaves) while most Saijin were just called by the names of the enshrined places or of the shrines and "kami "(god) in the suffix position.

Only a few shrines, such as Ise-jingu Shrine or Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine, had Saijin whose names were expressly recorded in the Kojiki (the Records of Ancient Matters), the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), or the Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves); most Saijin were just called by the name of the place of enshrinement or by the name of the shrine with the word "kami "(god) added as a suffix.
sen.cmt: As far as I know, 記紀 is a Japanese term used to refer to the 古事記 and 日本書紀 and not the name of an actual book itself so it doesn't really seem necessary to use this term in the translation. It makes more sense to just give the names of the two books it actually refers to.
sen.e: Only a few shrines, such as Ise-jingu Shrine or Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine, had Saijin whose names were expressly recorded in the Kojiki (the Records of Ancient Matters), the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), or the Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves); most Saijin were just called by the name of the place of enshrinement or by the name of the shrine with the word "kami "(god) added as a suffix.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 10世紀ごろから、それまでの氏神・地主神としての性格だけでなく、火の神・水の神・木の神などの具体的な神徳・機能が附加されるようになった。
sen.e: Since around 10th century, in addition to existing characters as Ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) and Jinushigami (god of an area of land), specific divinities and roles, such as a god of fire, a god of water and a god of trees, were developed.

sen.e: In accordance with those divinities, Saijin transformed into anthropomorphic deities with names derived from gods and goddesses ofJapanese Mythology or with names end with "Mikoto","Hiko" or "Hime"(name suffix) instead of having just place names or shrine names.
